awd_abstract_narration: This research involves the acquisition and use of a Whole Arm              Manipulator (WAM).  The instrument will be used in three research               areas:  (a) WAM use in teleprogramming with feedback, (b) robotic               exploration of environments, and (c) dynamic control of multiple                robotic agents for manipulation of objects.  The WAM is a                       distributed control, four degree-of-freedom robot arm that is                   unique in that it has been specifically designed for whole arm                  manipulation.  Distributed control and effectors allow the arm to               be used in applications for which earlier hand/arm combinations                 were ineffective.                                                                    State-of-the-art research in robotics requires the acquisition             of the latest equipment to test new control and planning                        algorithms. Early work with robot arms involved arms that were                  connected to robot hands in which the sensors and controls resided.             This research was necessary to investigate gripping algorithms and              feedback control algorithms.  However, in order to investigate more             extensive use of robots, these algorithms need to be integrated                 with the movement of the arm itself.  The Whole Arm Manipulator                 funded by this grant allows for that integration.  The development              of good algorithms for the arm manipulation is crucial for the                  advancement of the use of robots in U.S. industry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
